subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: American pronunciation
msgSnippet: I am a writer and have used both Shavian and Quikscript in my work, mainly for making notes, but I did  write a  complete play in Shavian. A pace from the
messageBody:
I am a writer and have used both Shavian and Quikscript in my work,
mainly for making notes, but I did write a complete play in Shavian.
A pace from the manuscript, which i regret to say no longer exists,
served as the end piece in an exhibition of alphabetical matters is the
UK many years ago. I was pleased to have had the opportunity to
communicate by mail with Mr. Read at that time.
About the matter of English and American forms: it might be noticed
that in the first American review of Quikscript, Warren Smith pointed
out that it had a built in British accent. But both Shavian and
Quikscript are, like most shorthand systems, phonetic in character, so
the writer's native accent will show up in some words without loss of
clarity. The book "Shaw on Language" gathers the materials that
inspired Kingsley Read to enter the Shaw legacy contest and later to
develop Quikscript. It might be noted that dropping the "c" before "k"
from Quickscript is phonetically sound, however strange the word may
look. Russell

On Dec 23, 2004, at 2:29 PM, Paige Gabhart wrote:

>  
>
>  
>
> "I despise a world which does not feel that music is a higher
> revelation than all wisdom and philosophy."
> -Ludwig van Beethoven
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Joe [mailto:allegrox_2000@...]
> Sent: Thursday, December 23, 2004 6:08 AM
> To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: American pronunciation
>
>  
>
>
>  > Correct me if I'm wrong, but I get the impression that Quikscript
> has
> > developed standard Quikscript spellings based on American
> > pronunciations.
> >
> > I speak British English, although I'm perfectly comfortable hearing
> > American English. When it comes to spontaneously writing Quikscript,
> > however, I write the British way, and have had cause for pause while
> > reading examples of Quikscript spelt the American way. Of course, the
> > difficulty lasts just a moment, but the experience gave rise to the
> > reflection that one of the factors that makes English a worldwide
> > language is that the spelling (however atrociously complicated and
> > irregular) is understood all over the English-using world,
>
>  
>
> This strikes me as the same argument for the Chinese continuing to use
> their form of writing because it enables Mandarin and Cantonese
> speakers to read what the other has written even though their
> languages are mutually unintelligible.  I would assume that most
> English speakers would not want our method of writing to become more
> ideographic than it currently is.
>
>  
>
> If, in fact, English is becoming a worldwide language, I believe it is
> due primarily to political and economic factors.  I cannot take
> seriously the idea that the consistent (and abominable) spelling of
> T.O. has much effect on the spread of English.  If that were the case,
> what would account for the decline of French as the language of
> diplomacy?  Is it not spelt the same all over the world?
>
>  
>
> I am a U.S. citizen.  I corresponded with a New Zealander in
> Quikscript (this is Read’s spelling, by the way, and recent posts by
> dshepx on the Shavian site persist in spelling it incorrectly: 
> “Quickscript”) in the mid-1970s.  I found it delightful that his
> accent came through in his letters.  Yes, occasionally, I was a little
> slow in deciphering some words, but it was never a problem which
> interfered with communication.
>
>  
>
> I would agree that consistent spelling would aid reading speed, but I
> don’t think it needs to be a “cultural fetish” as Mr. Read put it.  I
> do not believe that the number of words that would be spelt
> dramatically differently from one accent to another would pose an
> insurmountable communication problem.   The idea that there is one and
> one only “correct” spelling needs to be laid to rest.  I think the
> idea of correct spelling came about through the hegemony of printers
> and because of the difficulty of conformity with a T.O. standard for
> many people because it is so “atrociously complicated and irregular.” 
> I believe it is accurate to say that in the late sixteenth century few
> people believed there was one “right” way to spell a word.  The
> purpose of writing is communication, and if a reader can understand
> the words the writer wrote, even if some of them are spelt differently
> than the reader would have spelt them, then communication has taken
> place even if sticklers for uniformity don’t like it.
>
>  
>
>  (despite
> > discrepancies betwen Ameican and English spellings). Differences in
> > pronunciation don't come in the way. For example, while I find it
> hard
> > to understand Australian speech, I have no problems with Australian
> > English as expressed in newspapers or internet sites.
> >
> > I remember the story of the Australian who woke up in a hospital bed
> > and saw a friend in the next bed. He asked, "Did you come here to
> > die?" Replied his friend, "Yes, to die!" For any who have never heard
> > an Australian speaking, the dialogue went thus: "Did you come here
> > today?" "Yesterday."
> >
> > Imagine an Australian writing the words "today" and "yesterday" in
> > Quikscript the way he pronounces it! Neither the Englishman nor the
> > American would be likely to guess what it means.
> >
> > What do you feel about standardizing Quikscript spellings to the
> sound
> > of British English? The argument in favor would be that it is
> > understood in all the former British colonies, probably including the
> > USA.
>
>  
>
> This is an amusing anecdote, but it does not reflect reality.  If an
> American in the hospital ward could figure out what was being
> communicated, then so could a reader.  For example, even if the words
> sounded like “yes, to die” to the American, it would be written as one
> word since “yesterday” is one word.  Surely, this would be contextual
> clue to even the densest reader.
>
>  
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
